Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Constitutive and Inducible Predation Defenses in Cyanobacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
Terrestrial plants have diverse and sophisticated mechanisms for defending against predation and pathogens, but the defenses of photosynthetic microbes in aquatic ecosystems are much less well understood. Synechococcus are aquatic/marine cyanobacteria that substantially contribute to global primary productivity. This project will employ two main approaches to study Synechococcus defenses against protist predators. Experiments will examine the mechanism(s) by which cell surface proteins provide a constitutive (continuously expressed) defense and assay the generality of this defense among Synechococcus strains and against diverse predator types. Secondly, co-culture techniques, in which Synechococcus are grown in the presence of predators, will be used to characterize protein-based induced defenses that may arise in response to predation. The formation of aggregates as a possible induced defense by Synechococcus will also be examined in field and laboratory settings. Aggregate formation is important for the biogeochemistry and ecological functioning of planktonic communities since aggregates can be the site of unique biogeochemical processes. The research is cross-cutting on a number of levels: it examines constitutive and induced defenses in both controlled laboratory and natural settings; it leverages the suite of available Synechococcus genomes to enable a mechanistic investigation of microbial defense processes; and it represents a synthesis of ecological and genomic approaches to the study of microbial interactions that are fundamental to biogeochemical cycling and the maintenance of biodiversity in aquatic ecosystems.

Broader impacts of this project include support of graduate and undergraduate students, including ethnic minority participants in Shannon Point Marine Center's Multicultural Initiatives in Marine Science Undergraduate Program (MIMSUP). Other impacts include development of instructional modules for elementary and high school students, and maintenance and distribution of culture collections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated interactions between the cyanobacteria Synechococcus, one of the most abundant and important primary producers in the ocean, and the protists that prey on these tiny (1 µm) algal cells. Our main avenue of investigation used mutants in Synechococcus cell surface proteins to test whether the presence of these proteins acted as a defense against predation. We focused on one of the numerous clades, or taxonomic subgroups, of Synechococcus – specifically, Clade III, which possess a unique form of non-flagellar motility. Clade III Syneochoccus are primarily found in low-nutrient oceanic waters. Contrary to the predictions of our defense hypothesis, we found that the large protein SwmA, which forms a paracrystalline matrix (S layer) completely surrounding the cell, actually makes Synechococcus more vulnerable to protist predators. Mutants lacking SwmA were preyed upon at a lower rate than wild-type cells by both ciliates and flagellates, which are thought to be the major predators of Synechococcus in both marine and freshwater ecosystems. Based on knowledge of S layer properties in bacteria that are human pathogens and probiotics, we speculate that the Synechococcus S layer promotes attachment to the feeding capture structures of protist predators. If these findings are broadly representative of S layer-bearing Synechococcus and their predators, they imply that selective pressures other than predation must have driven the evolution and persistence of S layers in this subgroup of Synechococcus. Clade-specific measurements of ecological processes will be needed to determine the relationship between Synechococcus diversity and their ecological niches.

Other lines of investigation into Synechococcus predator-prey ecology were also undertaken. Numerous experiments examined whether morphological variability (formation of clumps of cells, or long ‘filamentous’ forms, as sometimes occurs in seawater-based culture medium) was related to the presence of protist predators or dissolved compounds from predator cultures. That is, could variations in morphology also act a defense by transforming Synechococcus cells into a size or shape that makes them unavailable to protist predators? We found no consistent evidence for a relationship between Synechococcus morphology and predator-derived substances. In an extensive field investigation of local (Salish Sea, Washington, USA) Synechococcus ecology, we found that Synechococcus abundance was negatively correlated with salinity during two summer-fall seasons (2011, 2012). In addition, we found that heterotrophic dinoflagellates appeared unexpectedly important as consumers of Synechococcus in these productive coastal waters.

Broader impacts of this project included supervised independent research projects by six undergraduates, four who were participants in Shannon Point Marine Center’s Multicultural Initiatives in Marine Science Undergraduate Program (MIMSUP), and two who were participants in our summer Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. Two Western Washington University graduate students also participated in the research, gaining extensive laboratory and field research experience. The grant partially supported maintenance of our culture collection of alveolates (ciliates and dinoflagellates), enabling us to share these cultures with colleagues from other institutions for broad use in ecological, physiogical, and molecular studies.
